question_name: What is the characteristic finding in lichen planus?
question_description: Identify the primary clinical feature of lichen planus.
subject: Dermatology

options.name: Wickham striae
options.description: Wickham striae are fine white lines on the surface of lichen planus lesions.

options.name: Butterfly rash
options.description: Butterfly rash is characteristic of lupus erythematosus.

options.name: Herald patch
options.description: Herald patch is a feature of pityriasis rosea.

options.name: Koebner phenomenon
options.description: Koebner phenomenon can occur in lichen planus but is not its primary feature.

question_name: Which condition is characterized by target lesions?
question_description: Identify the dermatological condition associated with target lesions.
subject: Dermatology

options.name: Erythema multiforme
options.description: Erythema multiforme is characterized by target lesions.

options.name: Psoriasis
options.description: Psoriasis does not typically present with target lesions.

options.name: Lichen planus
options.description: Lichen planus presents with flat-topped, purple papules.

options.name: Rosacea
options.description: Rosacea is characterized by facial redness and pimples.

question_name: What is the hallmark feature of pemphigus vulgaris?
question_description: Identify the primary characteristic of pemphigus vulgaris.
subject: Dermatology

options.name: Acantholysis
options.description: Acantholysis, or loss of keratinocyte adhesion, is the hallmark of pemphigus vulgaris.

options.name: Subepidermal blistering
options.description: Subepidermal blistering is seen in bullous pemphigoid, not pemphigus vulgaris.

options.name: Hyperkeratosis
options.description: Hyperkeratosis is a feature of chronic eczema and psoriasis.

options.name: Granuloma formation
options.description: Granuloma formation is seen in conditions like sarcoidosis.

question_name: Which type of hypersensitivity reaction is involved in allergic contact dermatitis?
question_description: Identify the type of hypersensitivity reaction responsible for allergic contact dermatitis.
subject: Dermatology

options.name: Type I
options.description: Type I hypersensitivity is immediate and includes conditions like anaphylaxis.

options.name: Type II
options.description: Type II hypersensitivity involves cytotoxic reactions, such as hemolytic anemia.

options.name: Type III
options.description: Type III hypersensitivity involves immune complexes, seen in conditions like lupus.

options.name: Type IV
options.description: Type IV hypersensitivity is a delayed reaction, as seen in allergic contact dermatitis.

question_name: What is the primary treatment for scabies?
question_description: Identify the most common treatment used for scabies.
subject: Dermatology

options.name: Topical steroids
options.description: Topical steroids are not used to treat scabies.

options.name: Antifungal creams
options.description: Antifungal creams are not effective against scabies mites.

options.name: Permethrin cream
options.description: Permethrin cream is the first-line treatment for scabies.

options.name: Oral antibiotics
options.description: Oral antibiotics are not used to treat scabies.

question_name: Which dermatological condition presents with a 'herald patch'?
question_description: Identify the condition characterized by the presence of a herald patch.
subject: Dermatology

options.name: Pityriasis rosea
options.description: Pityriasis rosea typically begins with a herald patch followed by a generalized rash.

options.name: Psoriasis
options.description: Psoriasis does not typically begin with a herald patch.

options.name: Lichen planus
options.description: Lichen planus does not present with a herald patch.

options.name: Erythema multiforme
options.description: Erythema multiforme is characterized by target lesions, not a herald patch.

question_name: Which skin infection is caused by group A Streptococcus?
question_description: Identify the skin infection commonly caused by group A Streptococcus.
subject: Dermatology

options.name: Impetigo
options.description: Impetigo is commonly caused by group A Streptococcus and presents with honey-colored crusts.

options.name: Tinea corporis
options.description: Tinea corporis is a fungal infection, not caused by bacteria.

options.name: Herpes simplex
options.description: Herpes simplex is a viral infection, not caused by bacteria.

options.name: Scabies
options.description: Scabies is caused by mites, not bacteria.

question_name: Which vitamin deficiency can lead to the development of pellagra?
question_description: Identify the vitamin deficiency that causes pellagra.
subject: Dermatology

options.name: Vitamin A
options.description: Vitamin A deficiency leads to night blindness and xerosis.

options.name: Vitamin C
options.description: Vitamin C deficiency leads to scurvy.

options.name: Niacin (Vitamin B3)
options.description: Niacin deficiency leads to pellagra, characterized by dermatitis, diarrhea, and dementia.

options.name: Vitamin D
options.description: Vitamin D deficiency leads to rickets and osteomalacia.

question_name: Which dermatological condition is associated with gluten sensitivity?
question_description: Identify the condition that is often seen in patients with gluten sensitivity.
subject: Dermatology

options.name: Psoriasis
options.description: Psoriasis is not specifically associated with gluten sensitivity.

options.name: Dermatitis herpetiformis
options.description: Dermatitis herpetiformis is strongly associated with gluten sensitivity and celiac disease.

options.name: Lichen planus
options.description: Lichen planus is not specifically associated with gluten sensitivity.

options.name: Rosacea
options.description: Rosacea is not specifically associated with gluten sensitivity.

question_name: Which condition is characterized by a 'sandpaper' texture of the skin?
question_description: Identify the condition that presents with a rough, sandpaper-like texture on the skin.
subject: Dermatology

options.name: Actinic keratosis
options.description: Actinic keratosis presents with rough, sandpaper-like lesions due to sun damage.

options.name: Seborrheic dermatitis
options.description: Seborrheic dermatitis presents with greasy, flaky scales, not a sandpaper texture.

options.name: Psoriasis
options.description: Psoriasis presents with thick, silvery scales, not a sandpaper texture.

options.name: Tinea versicolor
options.description: Tinea versicolor presents with hypopigmented or hyperpigmented patches, not a sandpaper texture.
